results.title: The Town That Dreaded Sundown
results.brief_description: A Texas Ranger hunts for a hooded serial killer terrorizing the residents of a small town, set in 1946 Arkansas. Loosely based on a true story.

results.title: The Town that Dreaded Sundown
results.brief_description: A masked maniac terrorizes the same small community where a murderer known as the Phantom Killer struck decades earlier.

constellations_other.name: Thomas Edison
constellations_other.description: Thomas Edison helped establish cinema as an art-form and mass entertainment. Many of his early films were short and showed everyday activities like riding a bicycle.

results.title: The Town of no return. The Gravediggers. The Cybernauts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Avengers”.
The Town of no return: Steed and Mrs Peel are sent to the sleepy seaside town of Little Bazeley to investigate the disappearance of four agents. In a town where nobody is what they seem, Peel and Steed disguise themselves as a primary school teacher and property developer and stay at a local hotel called the Gremlin. The highlight of the episode is a leather clad Peel tied down with horse riding apparel. “The Gravediggers”: there’s interference in sector three on the radar, leading to a fear of undetected nuclear weapons. Steed and Mrs Peel head to the town of Prinby, located in the heart of sector three and the burial place of Dr Hubert Marlowe, recently deceased expert in the field. Peel goes undercover as a Nurse at a hospice for railwaymen while Steed visits the benefactor of the establishment. Highlights of the episode include a miniature train ride and Mrs Peel tied to the railway tracks, complete with accompanying music, fitting for a damsel in distress. “The Cybernauts”: three electronics experts are killed by a tall man with brute strength and the number is increasing. They all had an appointment with the Harachi Corporation, an electronics company who have created a new circuit element for transistors. The trail leads Steed and Mrs Peel to United Automation where a wheelchair bound scientist is building an army of radio controlled cybernauts. A highlight of the episode involves Mrs Peel doing karate - in a skirt.

results.title: The Town mouse and the country mouse
results.creator_credit: Evelyn Lambart, Kathleen Shannon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Evelyn Lambert’s well-known style of animation using paper figures and brightly coloured backgrounds, based on an Aesop fable. Tells the simple story of two mice with different lifestyles and suggests that it is far better to live simply and in peace than live in luxury amidst danger

results.title: The Towering inferno
results.creator_credit: John Guillermin, Irwin Allen, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: A skyscraper and am all-star cast go up in flames in this classic 70s disaster movie. To celebrate the construction of the Glass Tower, the world’s tallest building, architect Doug Roberts and builder James Duncan hold a gala event on the highest floors. The trouble is that Duncan’s son-in-law and electrical subcontractor, Roger Simmons, installed faulty wiring throughout the 138-story tower to save money. While the town VIPs enjoy the party, a security guard wonders why his equipment is malfunctioning, only to discover that a burnt-out circuit breaker has ignited some rubbish on the 85th floor, which is swiftly turning the skyscraper into a “towering inferno”. It is then up to Roberts and Fire Chief O’Hallorhan to find a way to stop the blaze. Cast includes Steve McQueen, Paul Newman, William Holden, Faye Dunaway, Fred Astaire, Richard Chamberlain, Jennifer Jones, O.J. Simpson, Robert Vaughn, Robert Wagner and more…

results.title: The Touch
results.brief_description: Ingmar Bergman’s first English language film continues his investigation of the human psyche and contemporary existential anguish and alienation. Elliott Gould is an American archaeologist visting Sweden who is welcomed into the house of Andreas and Karin (Max Von Sydow and Bibi Andersson). The American falls in love with Karin and the ensuing relationship forces her to examine her beliefs regarding marriage, family and status. However, as her affair continues she is forced to re-evaluate what it is that has drawn her to the American. Their relationship is frustrated by the insecurities and silences of people unable to find ways of communicating desire and truth. As in all his films, Bergman’s “The Touch” is part of an imtimate cinematic exploration: intense, controversial and painfully honest. Bergman’s remarkable ouvre is one of cinema’s most outstanding pleasures and the cinematography is by his longtime collaborator, Sven Nykvist.

results.title: The Top few inches
results.creator_credit: Jerry Krepakevich and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Depicts impact of farming on the soils of Canada from the 1930s to the present. Shows soil erosion caused by poor farming techniques as well as leaching and salting due to irrigation. Emphasizes new practice of zero tillage and presents solutions to soil and land management.

results.title: The Top end
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Bayside reflections: Port Phillip Bay on film”.
Final part of a most comprehensive and fascinating two part history of Port Phillip Bay, dating back from the 1880s to present times and incorporating archival footage, both professional and amateur, to cover over a century of settlement in Port Phillip Bay. Part two focuses on the northern end of Port Phillip Bay, particularly the areas of Port Melbourne and St Kilda reflecting on their maritime histories and the inevitable changes each city has undergone over the last hundred years or so. From the days of royal visits arriving at St Kilda Pier to the huge passenger liners and warships docking at Port Melbourne’s Station Pier, through to remembering St Kilda when it was “the place in which to be seen” - Melbourne’s favourite playground for fun and leisure, swimming and sailing - to today’s commercial developments and resident protests to maintain the architectural heritage of both Port Melbourne and St Kilda. Broken up into six segments, this documentary also covers some of the Bay’s well-known sea baths, piers and beaches, famous (and some infamous) celebrities, politicians and sporting personalities, historical landmarks, buildings and events and provides some rare and nostalgic images of bygone times. Commentary by Paul Higgins.
